key_mistakes.reason: This move doesn't directly address the immediate pressure on the knight on c6 and allows White to capture and double Black's pawns.
Moving the knight to e5 allows Black to develop counterplay, but it weakens the control over the center and the d4 pawn.
This move is passive and doesn't put enough pressure on White's center. It also blocks the queen's defense of the b8 square.
This move weakens Black's pawn structure and fails to develop any pieces actively, allowing White to gain initiative.
This is a blunder because it allows White to increase pressure on the f6 knight, leading to tactical complications.
Castling kingside exposes Black's king to a pawn storm and tactical threats, especially with White's pieces aimed at the kingside.
This move weakens the kingside and does not contribute to Black's development or defense.
Pushing the g-pawn leaves Black's kingside very exposed and allows White's pieces to infiltrate.
This pawn push leads to further weakening of Black's kingside and allows White to open lines after hxg4.
Capturing the e5 pawn allows Black to gain control of the open d-file and increase pressure on White's position.
Moving the queen to d7 doesn't address the issues with Black's position and leaves the king vulnerable.
This move does not improve White's position significantly and misses an opportunity to apply pressure with b5.

recommendations: Focus on developing pieces efficiently in the opening phase.
Avoid unnecessary pawn moves that weaken your king's position.
Pay attention to pawn structure and control of the center.
Try to foresee tactical threats and avoid moving pieces into vulnerable positions.
